note.body:
I'm no maintainer, but I recommend the following:

1) choose three different, but popular distributions: Ubuntu (deb), Arch (aur) and Fedora (rpm). 

-------

2) either install each one on your computer in a multi-boot setting or make virtual machines of them. You do not need to document this part.

-------

3) For each, install and document dependencies that are installable from their respective repos. 
Example: 

*For Ubuntu 18.04 LTS
```
sudo apt install libvirt0 unzip
```

*For Fedora 29
```
-command goes here-
```

etc

-------

4) Document any other packages that you'll have to build from source. 

Example1:

*Build download123
```
wget https://127.0.0.1/com/download123.tar.gz
Untar command download123.tar.gz download123; cd download123
./configure
make
sudo make install
```


Example2:

*Add download123 repo
```
sudo add-apt-repository somerepo/something -y
sudo apt install download123
```

Example3:
```
git clone https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-boxes
cd gnome-boxes
meson --buildtype release ./ ./src/build
```

-------

5) Example command to run it

*Run download123

```
download123 -abc somefile
```

I wouldn't mind writing up some distro specific instructions myself, but first I need at least one example of a build, because I can't seem to figure it out by myself.

events.target_title: [BZ#755950] Feature: Column/Block Mode Editing

note.body:
Merely as additional evidence of this feature being relatively widespread, the following editing environments provide rectangular-region editing:
1. Emacs
1. Mac OSX
1. WindowsNT & later (especially in Microsoft Word)
1. Eclipse

Merely as collecting the maximal set of requirements/objectives/perceived-by-some-user-expectations, customarily the rectangular region editing includes the following broad modes (ignoring handling corner cases as not-broad modes of operation):
*  **rectangular cut** (to & from the same shaped rectangle)
*  **rectangular congruent paste** (to & from the same shaped rectangle, as overtly-rectangular-selected destination rectangle)
*  **rectangular extrapolating-tile paste** (from smaller origin rectangle [either in-situ via copy or on clipboard/kill-ring via cut] to larger destination rectangle, repeating the smaller rectangle as repeating tiles to fill out larger rectangle, clipping vertically and/or horizontally if larger destination rectangle width and/or height is not an integer multiple of the smaller origin rectangle)
*  **rectangular paste at linear-editing cursor** (i.e., not overtly selecting a destination rectangle), where cursor is upper-left of destination rectangle and column number is the left side of destination rectangle for each line
*  **rectangular linear paste** (from origin linear in-situ copy or clipboard/kill-ring cut to destination overtly-selected rectangle)
*  **rectangular insert typing** (select a zero-width rectangle, then type on multiple lines in insert mode)
*  One that I have never seen/noticed, but it would be orthogonal:  **rectangular overwrite typing** (select a zero-width rectangle, then type on multiple lines in overwrite mode, when linear editing is in overwrite mode)

OP is most likely wanting "rectangular insert typing" to select a zero-width rectangle at the left of the to-be-commented-out lines, then typing # or // or -- whichever is the comment-to-end-of-line syntax in that programming language.

events.target_title: Unix Line Endings

note.body:
@Desposyni, I think that you are more-clearly revealing where the weak links in the line-ending chain might be in this follow-up of yours.  You are describing a variety of use-cases in your follow-up, whereas the original submission above seems to unintendedly call to mind the canonical use-case of "I open a pair of corresponding files, then merge or edit, then the line-endings get messed up in that file", which is most likely not the use-case that has your line-ending bug at all.  Your line-ending bug seems to focus on *what* (line-ending convention) is be *preserved* from *where* (i.e., which origin) over *how big* of a scope, *when* synthesizing an output file manually via ad hoc editing/merging techniques (that differ from the canonical workflow).  This (what, where, how big, when) coordinate that you are evoking is different in some way than the (what, where, how big, when) coordinate in the canonical use-case.

Your follow-up seems to indicate that the line-ending buggy use-case is something in the vicinity of some X in the universe has the line-endings that you don't want, then your output unwittingly _preserves_ line-endings from X as the desirable referent instead of using as referent the origin file that you as a human being are focusing on and copying from.  For anyone trying to reproduce this problem, honing in on finding the X from which LF is being /preserved/ might be quite revealing in finding @Desposyni's bug in the various ad-hoc "I synthesized an output file manually" use-cases.

events.target_title: Unix Line Endings

note.body: @kaiw, @Desposyni cannot (easily) attach the UI events that he is invoking to accomplish his ad-hoc editing/merging/copying-intertwined use-case.  There are *static* files (which could be attached, as you requested, seemingly focusing on Meld's canonical use-case).  Then disjointly, there is *dynamic* synthesis of fresh file content (which cannot [easily] be attached as a recording of HMI events).

events.target_title: AM/PM not working / not translated in German

note.body:
Hey Tim!

>  This is a duplicate of https://gitlab.gnome.org/Teams/Translation/de/issues/7 , but since there is some discussion here, let's continue here.

I was/am in contact with one of the translators, "Bernd", who told me at the duplicate issue #7 that he fixed that and it will be online with the next gnome version. When 3.32 got available, I tried it out but it didn't work, so I asked him by email and he asked me to create an issue here again, because he doesn't have so much time to investigate this currently.
So, sorry for the duplicate, just want to see that getting fixed! :)

>  I can fix that, but I'm not sure that AM/PM are supported by the German locale.

Well, I noticed that Gnome Weather (and the widget of it in the top bar below your calendar, next to your notifications) supports am/pm since 3.32, it got translated to "VORM./NACHM.". And generally all DEs I tried out so far support AM/PM, some of them translated it to "VORM./NACHM." and some of them just used the 12h format, without any PM/AM text next to it (I think even Windows is doing it like that).

I have 1-2 friends who moved here to Austria and they still use the AM/PM 12h format for their devices, even with the language set to DE, that's why I even got into this issue! And, as said above, if there is an option, it should work :) .. but keep in mind, that I'm just an end user here, so I can't tell you if it would technically work or not.

events.target_title: Allow suspend with external monitor connected

note.body:
> I fear this is a bit too much of a corner case.

Is it really? I frequently work in coworking spaces where it's common to plug in an external display at "hot desks", but not an external keyboard because there often isn't one available, and people aren't carrying around one of their own. Also, not to mention beamers / big displays in meeting rooms :) Another side effect is that the external display becomes the primary one, so suddenly some applications are moved to the external display which is quite jarring.

To me it just seems very unexpected behaviour, and I thought it was a bug at first before I found out the reasoning behind it (which does make sense too, but doesn't apply to my workflow).

That said, I found an easy workaround by simply locking the screen first, after that I can close the lid and it will suspend as expected.

> Oh, I doubt we can reliably detect whether there is an external keyboard/mouse attached.

Fair enough, this was only a suggestion to avoid introducing a setting ;-)

events.target_title: Allow suspend with external monitor connected

events.target_title: Insane disk thrashing / optimize dconf's database IO access

note.body:
Here's an idea.

Stop doing whatever you're doing and switch to a properly written disk backend, e.g. SQLite or DB4.

I've never seen applications which rape my disk so much.

events.target_title: Insane disk thrashing / optimize dconf's database IO access

note.body:
Nice of you Philip!

You didn't pay attention to the egregious bug, instead you noticed the word "rape" (which is **appropriate** considering the bug's gravity).

Let's all be driven by the letter of the Code of Conduct and ignore properly filed bug reports because they are hurting your feelings.

If dconf had been written **properly** and didn't cause **excessive** disk usage, this bug report would have never been filed in the first place.

events.target_title: Insane disk thrashing / optimize dconf's database IO access

note.body:
If you think this bug report is invalid, go ahead and close it.

If you have so much spare time as to discuss a single inappropriate word (which is highly debatable because dconf does **exactly** that to my SSD) then maybe some people shouldn't work as developers and switch to politics, social workers or something else where your talents in appropriateness will be welcomed.

events.target_title: Insane disk thrashing / optimize dconf's database IO access

note.body: I will try to abstain from using words which could be deemed inappropriate for the time being. I'm sorry if I hurt someone's feelings and I suggest that we switch to the bug report instead.

events.target_title: Insane disk thrashing / optimize dconf's database IO access

note.body:
It's hard to imagine that I will ever enter anyone's house under the pretext of having issues with this person. I do understand that by "house" you meant this very bug tracker but I believe it's more like a public place where people can communicate freely.

Also, just also, I didn't yell at anyone and I didn't say that this or that developer is a bad person and does bad things. I merely pointed you at dconf's abnormal behaviour and used the word which you believe is inappropriate. I will not use this word in this conversation ever again.

events.target_title: Insane disk thrashing / optimize dconf's database IO access

note.body:
While we are at it I strongly suggest that

1) dconf works with its configuration file **without** closing it, deleting it and creating a new one because it may cause **more** harm to the underlying filesystem than simply rewriting the file if necessary

2) introduce a variable in dconf's database which specifies how often dconf may flush the data to the disk and possibly specify the lower limit of 1 second and default to 10 seconds which seems more appropriate to me because certain brilliantly written applications update dconf's data at e.g. each step of window resize which causes thousands of configuration updates when you simply drag one of application window corners.

events.target_title: Insane disk thrashing / optimize dconf's database IO access

note.body:
It's all true but what about mousepad which abuses the dconf database on start-up? And I haven't checked other gnome applications. Will you file bug reports for each one of them? That doesn't make sense because it just proves my point: the dconf database might be abused and it's abused.

**Writes to the dconf database should be rate limited or its database must not be updated as often as it's currently done.**

events.target_title: Insane disk thrashing / optimize dconf's database IO access

note.body:
I'm appalled by your reply.

I'm using just two gnome applications and both exhibit the issue, yet you insist that this behaviour is correct. It's not and fail-safes should be employed because rewriting a file 100 times over when a broken app flushes 100 settings in a row is completely wrong.

I will raise this issue with distros and hopefully they'll implement rate-limiting or workarounds since you don't really want to cooperate.

Also, where's a bug report against MousePad? Also, have you begun checking other gnome applications which might call g_settings_apply() after writing out each setting?

And speaking of atomic rewrites which you deem necessary: SQLite/DB4 work just fine without doing that. What's the reason you don't use them? Dconf's stopgap solution doesn't work that well as I've demonstrated.

6. close main window.

events.target_title: Design an initial integration of the current DL API with gtranslator

note.body:
@dmustieles Just to make sure - are you talking about language under Language Settings in Translation Editor Profile in Preferences? So the idea would be to match that language with the one the user is selecting from DL?

What happens if the file language and the profile language are not the same? Does the language in preferences affect anything?

events.target_title: Design an initial integration of the current DL API with gtranslator

note.body:
From what I gathered, a single PO file is determined by module name, branch and language.

The URL of a single PO file seems to be
`https://l10n.gnome.org/POT/[module].[branch]/[module].[branch].[lang].po`
Can someone confirm or correct this, and provide more information?

To provide a PO file, we need three pieces of data (arguments): module name, branch, language.
Should it be possible to choose another branch or is it always master?

In order to get these arguments, we need to collect them from user (module, possibly branch) and/or preferences (language from profile settings).

I suggest adding a "Load" button to the gtranslator toolbar, which opens a dialog with (at least) two dropdowns:
1.  Team (language): we obtain the list by calling https://l10n.gnome.org/teams/json and fill the dropdown with the elements
  * We can preselect the language from the translator profile.
  * Question: do we allow changing the language, or disable the dropdown and set the value to the profile language?

2.  Module: we obtain the list by calling https://l10n.gnome.org/modules/json and fill the dropdown with the elements

3. Branch? If we were to include branch dropdown, a new endpoint would need to be added to DL API to get the available branches of a module.

When all the arguments are provided, we can show link to download the PO file if there is one, and load it into gtranslator.

On a module language page (e.g. https://l10n.gnome.org/vertimus/gtranslator/master/po/sl/), there is also state which seems to be inactive by most modules. Is this expected? Does it affect something and should it be taken into consideration?

events.target_title: Design an initial integration of the current DL API with gtranslator
Add "line interval selection" based file diff feature
Add "line interval selection" based file diff feature

note.body:
Ideally, I would expect the UI interaction to proceed as follows:
- The user opens two regular files for compare in Meld, the GUI shows the all-file comparison as usual
- There should be a pair of textboxes in the buttons bar, where to manually specify the line intervals to restrict comparison for both files, e.g. consider only lines 11 to 21 of first file and lines 11 to 20 of second file, a button 'Apply' to recompute the visual diff on the restricted selections, and another button to exit the restricted selection mode;
- Not specifying a line interval on one file and clicking Apply should take as input the entire file, while entering restricted mode anyway; not specifying a line interval on both files and clicking Apply should have no effect (Apply button could also be disabled in that case)
- Once clicked on Apply, the GUI shows only the above-mentioned diff, moreover, for implementation simplicity and coherence, the file modifications outside those intervals should be disabled when in restricted mode.
- From command line, it may be useful to add direct invocation parameters for restricted mode as well, e.g.
```shell
meld file1.cpp file2.cpp --lines1=11-21 --lines2=11-20
```

Screenshots with an example mockup modification are attached![before](/uploads/050976a3b720ac9bb83d0ce26c23c284/before.png)![after](/uploads/ba36c2b4fcb28bb14bad49cb4d474095/after.png)

events.target_title: Freezes when use GtkComboList  when appears-as-list is true and the number of items is large
Cannot save modified file: g-io-error-quark
Cannot cross compile from linux to windows

note.body:
Could someone test the attached patch? It seems to work for me, I'm able to build a statically-linked DLL for Windows in a cross-compiler.

The "trick" is to copy `rsvg_internals.lib` to `librsvg_internals.a` just after the `cargo build` command. This idea is borrowed from here:
https://aur.archlinux.org/cgit/aur.git/tree/makefile-fix.patch?h=mingw-w64-librsvg

I've also fixed the static build with this patch (#159). This is made possible based on the `noinst_LTLIBRARIES` variable and by generating a Libtool convenience library (`.la`). See:
https://github.com/kanru/libtool-rs

Not sure if this patch is correct (I don't have much experience in `Makefile` files). Before opening an merge request I want to discuss this first. You may use, modify, copy, and redistribute this patch, under the terms of your choice.

[0001-Fix-Windows-build-and-static-linking.patch](/uploads/b15021390a7d38b235c8416bd4c415fa/0001-Fix-Windows-build-and-static-linking.patch)

events.target_title: Cannot cross compile from linux to windows

note.body:
@ashie Try to configure with `LIBS="-lws2_32 -luserenv"`. I'm building with:
```
curl https://sh.rustup.rs -sSf | sh
source $HOME/.cargo/env
rustup target add x86_64-pc-windows-gnu

curl -L https://download.gnome.org/sources/librsvg/2.45/librsvg-2.45.4.tar.xz | tar -xJf -
cd librsvg-2.45.4

curl https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/librsvg/uploads/b15021390a7d38b235c8416bd4c415fa/0001-Fix-Windows-build-and-static-linking.patch | git apply -v

autoreconf
./configure \
  --host="x86_64-w64-mingw32" \
  --enable-static \
  --disable-shared \
  --disable-pixbuf-loader \
  --disable-gtk-doc \
  --disable-introspection \
  --disable-tools \
  LIBS="-lws2_32 -luserenv" \
  RUST_TARGET="x86_64-pc-windows-gnu" \
  RUSTFLAGS="-C panic=abort"
make RUSTFLAGS="-C panic=abort"
sudo make install-strip
```

note.body:
Sorry for the delayed response. You could fix the Linux build with this patch:

```diff
diff --git a/rsvg_internals/src/handle.rs b/rsvg_internals/src/handle.rs
index 1111111..2222222 100644
--- a/rsvg_internals/src/handle.rs
+++ b/rsvg_internals/src/handle.rs
@@ -1258,7 +1258,7 @@ impl PathOrUrl {
             .map_err(|_| ())
             .and_then(|utf8| Url::parse(utf8).map_err(|_| ()))
             .and_then(|url| {
-                if url.origin().is_tuple() {
+                if url.origin().is_tuple() || url.scheme() == "file" {
                     Ok(PathOrUrl::Url(url))
                 } else {
                     Ok(PathOrUrl::Path(url.to_file_path()?))
```

When performing a `make check` I see:
```
test handle::tests::path_or_url_unix ... ok
test handle::tests::path_or_url_unix_url ... ok
test handle::tests::path_or_url_windows ... ok
test handle::tests::path_or_url_windows_url ... ok
```

Answering your questions:
- I think GLib expect UTF-8 filenames (even on Windows, but I'm not sure). I'm able to load a file on Windows named `йцук.svg` on your `windows-cross-compilation` branch.
- I've also looked into `g_file_new_for_commandline_arg`. It seems they use [`g_path_is_absolute`](https://developer.gnome.org/glib/stable/glib-Miscellaneous-Utility-Functions.html#g-path-is-absolute) to detect if it should use `g_file_new_for_path`, see:
  https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/blob/1a03ebc43ac1ef4b803fb324d809e88f52d54c0d/gio/gfile.c#L6647-6651

I don't think `rsvg_handle_new_from_file` should be deprecated, it's a very convenient function.

If you wondered why I'm cross-compiling the latest versions of librsvg,
I do this for the Windows builds of libvips. See: https://github.com/libvips/build-win64-mxe.

Indeed, the patch I've proposed relies too much on environment variables. Maybe it's reasonable to drop autotools and switch to the Meson build system? Pango, gdk-pixbuf and GLib have followed the same path. I'm sure this makes cross compiling and maintenance easier. However, I'm not sure how Meson behaves with Rust/Cargo, https://github.com/mesonbuild/meson/pull/2617 might be relevant here.

@ashie If you want a simple cross build environment, you can use parts of this repo: https://github.com/libvips/build-win64-mxe.

events.target_title: NewAdwaita: change color scheme from warm to neutral
NewAdwaita: change color scheme from warm to neutral

note.body:
Thanks for comment.

I don't think arguing about luxury or more efficient style will lead us to right result. Many men, many minds. There is always will be a dissent. But we can find the right solution from technical point.

We know about checker shadow illusion. Almost the same with colors. If environment is almost gray but not quite, after few hours we wouldn't be able to find correct white balance for picture. Our eyes will adopt  for new "gray point" like they do it for light bulbs. That's why last versions of GIMP, Darktable, Lightroom, Blender, Photoshop etc all have precisely neutral gray or even black background.

If theme will be more like Ubuntu theme, warmth will be OK. I never had issues with GIMP look and feel on Ubuntu. When I open GIMP after a couple of months in Adwaita Dark my firsth thoughts are: "UWhy it so red? Oh, it's ok. Adwaita is blue. Ok, let's make it fullscreen". Old Adwaita was cold, new will be warm. Problem is still here. And now Adwaita Light will be affected.

That happends because of colors that pretends to be gray, but they actualy are not gray. Opposite side is Ubuntu theme which is not even close to be neutral. Imho Adwaita as being default GTK theme can't go in Ubuntu way. I think default GTK theme should be as neutral as it can be.

So If there is no reason to do these colors not gray, why we cant do them gray? Many users may not notice that, but it will make life happier for photographers and video makers.

As bonus GIMP may will use default GTK4 dark adwaita with no need to build custom color theme for application.

events.target_title: Gender-neutral language support

note.body:
@alexarnaud I wasn't thinking about modifying the voice output program, which is awesome. The problem is about the de-genderised text itself.

The idea was, more or less, to have another (optional) layer between the screen text and the Speech Dispatcher. This proposed layer would modify the screen text so the spanish "de-genderizations" are removed, then, the modified text will be passed to the Speech dispatcher.

My Linux distribution is Ubuntu, the command works well, the issue is, for example, when the command reads a de-genderised "nosotros", which is "nosotrxs" or "nosotres" (the first word is unpronounceable and second is unexisting).

Thank you for your interest and time!

[Probably a duplicate but still not fixed since 3.22] Systematic segmentation fault

note.body:
I have found a reliable way to reproduce this bug. I am using fcitx to input Chinese since ibus lacks some features I need. Due to the problem [fail to call fcitx](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Fcitx#Ctrl.2BSpace_fail_to_work_in_GTK_programs), I have the following set up with gsettings:
`gsettings set org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.xsettings overrides "{'Gtk/IMModule':<'fcitx'>}"`

This will cause gnome-tweaks to have segmentation fault for the following steps:
1. Open gnome-tweaks
2. Press Alt-tab to switch to another window
3. Gnome-tweaks segmentation fault

If I reset the value, i.e. `gsettings reset org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.xsettings overrides`, then gnome-tweaks no longer crashes. Thus a dirty workaround would be resetting the value before calling gnome-tweaks, and set back after gnome-tweaks returns. I think the main reason is that gnome-tweaks assume the use of ibus, and when this assumption does not hold (for some reason), it crashes.

Hope this can help solving the bug.

note.body:
> DO NOTE THAT IT does not handle the additional characters (outside the character set covered by EUC-JP) differently from other encodings such as EUC-JP-MS.

I meant to say obviously instead:
DO NOTE THAT IT handles the additional characters (outside the character set covered by EUC-JP) differently from other encodings such as EUC-JP-MS.

events.target_title: Failing to save modified files from MELD.

note.body:
I found an interesting exchange in python bug database.
https://bugs.python.org/issue23050

It mentions to add legacy Japanese encoding. OK, it asks for adding among other things, "eucjp_ms (euc-jp compatible with cp932)". I suspect a patch similar to the one proposed there was incorporated into python3, and the encoding is called EUC-JP-MS therein.
Problem is that the characset covered by EUC-JP is smaller than the one covered by EUC-JP-MS. 
Under linux (or for that matter traditional UNIX), a document encoded in EUC-JP only contain the characters in EUC-JP and not use the ADDITIONAL characters in cp932, etc. This means that python3's detector should state that my ~/.emacs file is EUC-JP. It is not incorrect to say that it is EUC-JP-MS, but the file uses only the subset (EUC-JP) of EUC-JP-MS and so the decoding should be EUC-JP (more popluar than EUC-JP-MS, as exemplified by the fact that Debian does not include EUC-JP-MS encoding at all, and nobody seems to have complained so far.)

Oh well. If there is a character table for EUC-JP-MS that I can feed to linux's locale data files, I can define "euc_JP.EUC-JP-MS" or some such encoding, and see if this lets MELD to save the files successfully.

I have tons of EUC-JP encoded files and it is not tenable to transform them all into UTF8, etc. since some files have encoding information as part of the file even...

events.target_title: Failing to save modified files from MELD.

note.body:
Very strange: on the same linux PC, "iconv -l" lists EUC-JP-MS as a valid encoding that it understands.
Can it be the future Japanese linux distribution ought to include EUC-JP-MS to cope with the mess of similar but incompatible charcter encodings?

I need some expert guidance here.

events.target_title: Failing to save modified files from MELD.

note.body:
I hasten to add two points.

1. My current LC_* LANG* settings are as follows.

It is quite common to use UTF8 for the current or new work and yet handle many document files in EUC-JP.
GNU Emacs handles such different encodings quite well, for example.

$ locale
LANG=ja_JP.UTF-8
LANGUAGE=
LC_CTYPE="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_NUMERIC="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_TIME="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_COLLATE="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_MONETARY="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_MESSAGES="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_PAPER="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_NAME="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_ADDRESS="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_TELEPHONE="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_MEASUREMENT="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_IDENTIFICATION="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_ALL=
ishikawa@ip030:/home/ishikawa$ 

2. After figuring out that there is a file with "EUC-JP-MS" in its name (see below), I tried to define the new encoding euc_JP.EUC-JP-MS EUC-JP-MS" on my linux PC. I rebooted it, but the MELD still fails to write the file with the same error messages on the console window.

```
ishikawa@ip030:/home/ishikawa$ mlocate EUC-JP-MS
/home/ishikawa/repos/emacs-25.1/admin/charsets/glibc/EUC-JP-MS.gz
/home/ishikawa/repos/emacs-25.2/admin/charsets/glibc/EUC-JP-MS.gz
/home/ishikawa/repos/emacs-25.3/admin/charsets/glibc/EUC-JP-MS.gz
/home/ishikawa/repos/emacs-26.1/admin/charsets/glibc/EUC-JP-MS.gz
/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/gconv/EUC-JP-MS.so
/usr/lib32/gconv/EUC-JP-MS.so
/usr/libx32/gconv/EUC-JP-MS.so
/usr/share/i18n/charmaps/EUC-JP-MS.gz
```
Locale creation.
```
ishikawa@ip030:/home/ishikawa$ grep -i euc /etc/locale.gen
ja_JP.EUC-JP EUC-JP
ja_JP.EUC-JP-MS EUC-JP-MS
# ko_KR.EUC-KR EUC-KR
# zh_TW.EUC-TW EUC-TW
```


And then I ran locale-gen and it ran successfully.
Reboot. But still no go.

So now my take is that since "iconv" seems to understand EUC-JP-MS, maybe python3's encode () function returns EUC-JP-MS, but
python3 itself is not yet ready to handle EUC-JP-MS and it may expect something like eucJP-MS or EUCJP-MS or whatever? 

Again, I need the opinion of an expert in this area.

note.body:
I am attaching the original file that caused the problem mentioned here.
(I renamed it from .emacs to meld-issue.txt)
step to reproduce:

1. Copy it to a new file.
2. Modifying it using, say, GNU Emacs which does not break the file's encoding.
3. Please recall that it is in EUC-JP encoding. 
4. Save the modification.
5.  Using MELD,  compare the original and the modified one and change the modified one to match the original.
6. Try closing the tab and save the file.
(of course you can simply create a duplicate file, compare them in MELD, touch one of them and try saving it before closing/exiting MELD.)

Voila! I believe you get the error unless there is a system-specific cause (due to available locale issues or external utility that may be used to detect file's encoding[meld-issue.txt](/uploads/742af7abd2bc3005befb9cef3a3fc3c9/meld-issue.txt).)

I am using Debian GNU/Linux stretch with some more up-to-date (bleeding edge) packages.

[meld-issue.txt](/uploads/c340e7e0e9fa0e9fc7dd1caac6eb6938/meld-issue.txt)

Thank you for your comment and attention.

here is the locale listing in an uncorrupted format.:


```
ishikawa@ip030:/home/ishikawa$ locale
LANG=ja_JP.UTF-8
LANGUAGE=
LC_CTYPE="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_NUMERIC="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_TIME="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_COLLATE="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_MONETARY="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_MESSAGES="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_PAPER="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_NAME="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_ADDRESS="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_TELEPHONE="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_MEASUREMENT="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_IDENTIFICATION="ja_JP.UTF-8"
LC_ALL=
ishikawa@ip030:/home/ishikawa$ 
```

> > Come to think of it, maybe merging files using MELD only handles ASCII files up to early this year.
> 
> No, we've handled unicode for... a very, very long time now.

I meant to say, that *I* used MELD to handle only ASCII files on *MY* PC up to early this year and that was why I may not have noticed the issue sooner.
(Mostly mozilla thunderbird source code).
This little hiccup prompted me to investigate other tools, most notably GNU Emacs's emerge mode (I think that is the name). There are pros and cons for each tool.
Definitely MELD wins handsomely when the changes are sparse and not so convoluted. Working with GUI to move a few lines right and left is the most intuitive way to merge the changes.

For a very complex change, I found that GNU Emacs's merge was very clever to handle the change in a clean manner which MELD failed. That was a surprise. GNU Emacs's emerge must have a wealth of built-in heuristics to interpret changes in an intuitive way.

Again thank yoy for the great package and attention to my bug report.

note.body:
I'm running fine with PRIME using the .desktop entry for greeter and session: (GDM 3.26.2.1)

`
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Name=Optimus
Exec=sh -c "xrandr --setprovideroutputsource modesetting NVIDIA-0; xrandr --auto"
NoDisplay=true
X-GNOME-Autostart-Phase=DisplayServer
`
This file is symlinked to both /etc/xdg/autostart for gnome-session and to /usr/share/gdm/greeter/autostart/ for greeter session


What is really missing is the flexibility to configure the X server for different sessions. I can see the case for this feature for optimus laptop owners who have outputs connected to a discrete card. 

I own a Thinkpad P52 with Intel and Nvidia. External ports are wired to Nvidia and I must run it to use them. Running nvidia X server adds 15-20W to my power budget when my laptop is idle. 
I can do emails, spreadsheets and simple typewriting on Intel only config. I can even do video production with BMD Resolve on intel only (when I don't need an external monitor) thanks to cuda working independently of X. 

So the idea is to:  
* make xorg.conf.d files so that the gdm greeter can start without any tweaks (on Intel in my case). 
* Modify session .desktop file to include some hints regarding the way X server should be started and some env variables be adjusted (ldpath to opengl libraries) for a particular session, falling back to default behavior in the absence of such hints.

Once these options are available, distributions may devise hardware detection scripts to enable PRIME based sessions in addition to default (intel based) sessions.

This is the 1st step to fix it. Alternative may be to move X server init to the .desktop file entirely.

I know that X is being replaced by wayland, but wayland doesn't show any interest in supporting optimus hardware.

GtkFlowBox: the orthogonal orientation always requests the most size it could possibly need

note.body:
This seems to be a direct consequence of dropping the two most useful modes when GtkFlowBox was adopted/adapted from EggWrapBox. There were originally three layout modes - (EGG_WRAP_ALLOCATE_FREE, _ALIGNED and _HOMOGENEOUS). 

The only mode that was included in GTK3+ (Homogeneous) was the one with maximum stability (i.e., the one that ensured that regardless of the changes the user made by resizing, the widget would remain the same size and so had to be the maximum width or height that might need to be requested when the window was squeezed in the other dimension).  It was probably a misnomer since "*_STABLESIZE" would be closer to the truth, otherwise it works like Aligned with fixed widths and heights based on the largest element contained.

I am using the _FREE mode from EggWrapBox in the port of XtrackCAD GTK3 to layout sets of tool icons with varying widths and ensure that the space used is optimal - and in that mode in EggWrapBox this behaviour doesn't happen - the height is minimized in horizontal layout and minimal width in vertical layout. I expect that _ALIGNED mode would be the same, looking at the code - but that obviously doesn't work well when the contained icons/elements have very different individual widths or heights -> lots of wasted space.

It would be nice if some of this extra functionality made its way back into GTK at some point - as it is we include EggWrapBox in our source tree and life goes on.

events.target_title: Support for Zstandard compressed files/archives

note.body:
ok, I tested your branch but without libarchive support. All works fine except of MIME detection.
Create a `tar.zst` file and then remove it's extension. Then open the file roller and drag&drop the file into it.

**Expected:** File Roller detected zstd file by first 4 magic bytes and opens it.

**Actual:** File Roller asks for creation a new archive with this file.

To fix that apply the patch:
```patch
Index: src/glib-utils.c
===================================================================
--- src/glib-utils.c	(revision a868c23b937a2ce0ff1a70030c551bee84e52b6e)
+++ src/glib-utils.c	(date 1567454909777)
@@ -1227,6 +1227,7 @@
 		{ 0,  4, "PK\003\004",                           "application/zip"             },
 		{ 0,  8, "PK00PK\003\004",                       "application/zip"             },
 		{ 0,  4, "LRZI",                                 "application/x-lrzip"         },
+		{ 0,  4, "\x28\xB5\x2F\xFD",                     "application/zstd"            },
 	};
 
 	int  i;
```

events.target_title: Support for Zstandard compressed files/archives

note.body:
Also I didn't tested yet libarchive support but please check MIME types list on `src/fr-archive-libarchive.c:94`. It looks like here is missing "application/zstd":

```patch
Index: src/fr-archive-libarchive.c
===================================================================
--- src/fr-archive-libarchive.c	(revision a868c23b937a2ce0ff1a70030c551bee84e52b6e)
+++ src/fr-archive-libarchive.c	(date 1567452547546)
@@ -92,6 +92,7 @@
 	"application/x-xz-compressed-tar",
 #if (ARCHIVE_VERSION_NUMBER >= 3003003)
 	"application/x-zstd-compressed-tar",
+	"application/zstd",
 #endif
 	"application/zip",
 	NULL
```

note.body: Interesting, just today I found that zstd can be compiled with lzma and gzip support. I guess that’s because ZStandard uses almost the same encoding algorithms like Z77 but maybe it reuses zlib. So maybe it is possible to get rid of the libarchive at all. Do you know if this possible?

events.target_title: Support for Zstandard compressed files/archives

note.body:
As far I remember the guess_type function works only by file extention. I tried to create a tar.zst file and then changed its extention to just `.tarzst`. Please try this maybe you’ll reproduce this case. But from another point of view we can get rid of this magic signatures at all and use glib which internally uses shared-mime-info library.
The library is a clone of libmagic (that is used by the `file` command) but with icons and the file type description.
But the shared-mime-info doesn’t supports yet zstd. I’ll send them PR today (it is half done) but anyway this may take some time while it will be accepted and all systems update the shared mime library.
So it still makes sense to add this magic bytes. Or from another point of view it’s not a big deal here because the files without extensions are not so common

Lollypop fails to start and process hangs
Lollypop fails to start and process hangs

note.body:
Yeah, I was running against the current master.  Removing lollypop.db allowed Lollypop to open, but I'm not too thrilled about losing all of my ratings and play history.  I was a few releases out of date prior to today, so perhaps a schema incompatibility came into play somewhere between now and when I last updated.  :shrug: 

In future versions, would it be possible to add an informative popup that lists startup errors and a possible explanation?  If not that, can Lollypop be made to exit gracefully if the lollypop.db file prevents it from starting?  The latter case would be much preferred over manually force-killing the process.

events.target_title: Lollypop fails to start and process hangs

note.body:
That DB version was 9 months old?  Here I thought it had only been a few months since my last upgrade.  :sweat:  

I did copy the lollypop.db prior to deleting it, so there's a backup in that sense.  I didn't do anything with dconf prior to upgrading Lollypop, though.  Would 923e8e7d allow that previous lollypop.db file to be used?

events.target_title: Lollypop fails to start and process hangs

note.body:
Sure, here it is.

[lollypop.db](/uploads/d31fe631e4119445d0496253f6649b56/lollypop.db)

events.target_title: Lollypop fails to start and process hangs

note.body:
It does work now, strangely.  I placed lollypop.db back into my existing Lollypop install (built from master) and also into a brand new install on a separate machine, and both started just fine.  My existing install doesn't display any of my previous listening history, but I don't think that's relevant to this specific issue.  The important thing is that the program starts, and I can always rebuild my activity over time.

I made a few suggestions above for including informational popups for general crashes or coding graceful exits for when there are problems with the DB (if that's really what prevented my original startup here).  Are either of those ideas worthwhile to you?  Feel free to close this ticket whether or not they are, since the original issue is now fixed.

This is great. Thank you. I see this is available in my distro's repositories as well. This fixes the situation in Gedit.

I still think this should be (available, installed by) default or at least as an option in anything that embeds the Gedit component. I rely on it in a multi dpi environment. I'm personally especially interested in Meld, and I don't see anywhere in Meld's preferences if using Gedit plugins is possible. I'll contact its developers and link to this issue.

events.target_title: Zoom using Ctrl+Wheel
Can't change default calendar for events

note.body:
Experiencing this in Calendar 3.30.0 on Ubuntu 18.04.1.

Now, instead of the first bug mentioned above, I experience a 'reverse' bug:
1. Open the Calendar Settings dialog.
1. Select a calendar, then click "Add new events to this calendar by default" to set it as default.
1. Exit the dialog.
1. Click on any day to open the New Event dialog.  It will show the _newly set_ default calendar, correctly.
1. Click the day again to close the New Event dialog.
1. Click the day again to show the New Event dialog.  It will now show the _previous_ default calendar (and the setting has been reset).

note.body: This was and still is an important issue, for there are important reasons to incorporate interactive GEGL ops into complicated plug-ins. If it is as easy to implement as implied in the previous discussion, it is disappointing and a serious deficiency now that GIMP has progressed all the way to 2.10.6.

events.target_title: Gimp-2.10.8-x86_64 crash at startup on mac os 10.11.6

note.body:
I have the same problem. I use 10.11.6 in a iMac Intel Core 2 Duo from 2007. Searching Google for the error that marked the crash, I arrived here. I have tried version b129 and it opens correctly and at the first.

This problem serves me for similar ones. I have more than fifty applications whose latest versions are hung, despite the developer says it is compatible with 10.11.I see that it is not easy to maintain compatibility backwards, and less with the changes that Apple hides in its evolution towards a completely closed and permanently updated system, at its own pace.

note.body:
This doesn't crash anymore with `gnome-control-center-3.32.1`.

Now, instead of crashing, nothing happens - the `No stylus found\nPlease move your stylus to the proximity of the tablet to configure it` is still displayed even when I move the stylus close to the screen.

events.target_title: Wacom: crashes when bringing the stylus close to the screen

note.body: Thanks for the info! It turns out there was no tablet description for the particular tablet in my X1 Yoga 3rd Gen. Copying one from the already-existing description for this laptop made Gnome Settings show the options: https://github.com/linuxwacom/wacom-hid-descriptors/issues/66#issuecomment-541572917

events.target_title: WIP: ES6 Modules

note.body:
As former NodeJS modules working group member, I'm with @RangerMauve and against `.mjs` as solution for anything.

Let's not repeat NodeJS mistakes where is not necessary. I wouldn't mind GJS being compatible with `.mjs` too but I don't think it needs it, for the simple reason GJS has nothing to do with CommonJS and npm and all other little reasons that made NodeJS take such difficult road, a road that will also allow the usage of `.js` as ESM too ... so ... why even bothering here?

I'd also advocate for not having any magic name resolution, standards are coming up with a better mapping proposal for the web that will be adopted in NodeJS too so that the resolution of `"thing"` can be resolved directly through such map (no magic `index.js` discovery).

Last, but not least, for backward compatibility, and friendly migration, reasons, I think `imports` should stick around to signal the script bit, and `import ...` or the dynamic `import(...)` to signal the native JS import.

If we'd like to offer scripts via dynamic `import(..., {mode: 'legacy'})` I think it'd be fine.

My 2 cents

events.target_title: WIP: ES6 Modules
WIP: ES6 Modules

note.body:
> It seems that most browser-based JS doesn't import directly from a URI because async loaders are not yet widely supported and most use cases of URI imports would do I/O? I think it would be important to dredge up some examples of prior art before making that decision.

The Web is already importing from URL thanks to projects such as [Pika CDN](https://www.pika.dev/cdn) that remove all the I/O you've mentioned, and `https://unpkg.com/` that enables ESM via `?module`

Also NodeJS is going to support URL protocols (i.e. for `file://...`), so I am not sure if there's any other prior art needed.

events.target_title: WIP: ES6 Modules

note.body:
Please note [import-maps](https://wicg.github.io/import-maps/) are on the standard path, and the browser there also reserved a `std:` protocol for native modules provided by the browser.

Maybe using `gir:` without the `//` part could also be an option, as reserved prefix, but I'm not sure at that point if going `gir:Gtk?v=3.0` would make sense, since AFAIK, and so far, `std:` has no versioning (but maybe they will have versioning at some point, although native APIs don't ship versioned on the Web, only features detection matters there).

events.target_title: WIP: ES6 Modules

note.body:
> if you were suggesting using `std:` for gir then I don't think it's a good idea.

not at all, I was eventually saying same as `std:` is reserved for Web/Browsers, but not as protocol (it's `std:module`, not `std://module`), maybe we could use `gi:`

However, I think `gi://` as special reserved protocol is a better choice, due ability to use `?v=3.0` as any other regular file/URL

events.target_title: Move tool doesn't work as expected with copied layers

note.body: Was the mode of the move tool "Move active layer" or "Pick a layer or guide"? In the later mode the move toll always move the most upper visible layer that is not necessary the selected one inside the layer panel.

events.target_title: Move tool needs to highlight objects

note.body: Also, if the move tool in it's "Move the active layer" mode it keeps a visible dotted outline of the original position while moving the layer. Same is not present when the "Pick layer or guide" mode is utilized. Maybe it should become a option for both modes.

events.target_title: Move tool doesn't work as expected with copied layers

note.body:
It actually is the intended behavior by the developers. "Pick a layer" mode always choose the most top layer with a visual pixel beneath the mouse pointer. This can be the active layer or another one, indicated by the form of the mouse pointer (crosshair - the active layer, hand-symbol - a non-active layer).
But I agree that it is confusing for new users, special when working with semi-transparency. Just choose "Move active layer" once and save the tool-settings under Preferences -> Tool Options if "Save tool options on exit" is not already marked.

Ah yes it is an abort, specifically an assert:

Nov 13 10:43:28 compy org.gnome.Shell.desktop[842]: **

Nov 13 10:43:28 compy org.gnome.Shell.desktop[842]: == Stack trace for context 0x55a248d89200 ==
Nov 13 10:43:28 compy audit[842]: ANOM_ABEND auid=1000 uid=1000 gid=1000 ses=2 pid=842 comm=4A532048656C706572 exe="/usr/bin/gnome-shell" sig=6 res=1
```

I've now rebuilt glib2 with debug symbols however I haven't seem to have gotten a crash yet but I am noticing these lines a lot in the logs:
```
Nov 14 13:54:26 compy gnome-shell[842]: Attempting to call back into JSAPI during the sweeping phase of GC. This is most likely caused by not destroying a Clutter actor or Gtk+ widget with ::destroy signals connected, but can also be caused by using the destroy(), dispose(), or remove() vfuncs. Because it would crash the application, it has been blocked and the JS callback not invoked.
Nov 14 13:54:26 compy gnome-shell[842]: The offending signal was destroy on ClutterClone 0x55c2f49774c0.
Nov 14 13:54:26 compy org.gnome.Shell.desktop[842]: == Stack trace for context 0x55c2f2330200 ==

gimp 2.10.8 crash
Add vector or raster digital signature

note.body: The ability to overlay an arbitrary image, like a signature, seems to go outside the very specific scope of the ink annotation, as laid out in the spec. Regardless of the details of and obstacles to an ink annotation implementation, overlaying an image is a hugely useful and general feature. What would be the best direction to explore hacking around this feature?

events.target_title: Add vector or raster digital signature

note.body: FWIW, after a bit of digging in evince and poppler I think that the best approach for adding an arbitrary image overlay is not the annotation, for which there seem to be no corresponding standard provision, but a simple image XObject, whose rendering is then appended to the rendering stream of the current page. However, this requires editing the document and the underlying poppler does not seem to be oriented towards editing or otherwise changing the PDF documents it parses, perhaps owing to its roots in xpdf codebase. Perhaps people with better experience in these codebases can chime in to comment.

Unnecessary logging (?) of media-keys plugin

note.body:
I have also been bitten by this (small) bug, while launching terminals from scripts (for student labs). I see a few problems:

- Ultimately all print* functions used for logging in gnome-terminal use terminal_fprintf (in terminal-options.c:45). It re-implements all the printing because it needs to prepend '#' at the start of every-line so as to not pollute the output of 'gnome-terminal -p'
- gnome-terminal uses its own logging levels (TerminalVerbosity enum distinct from GLogLevelFlags)
- the macros terminal_printerr* (terminal-options.h:181) seem to incorrectly call terminal_print_level instead of terminal_printerr_level hence the message at issue here are printed on stdout instead of stderr

 So, since gnome-terminal as such a peculiar printing mechanism (prepend each log line with '#') it seems fair for it to honor the GLogLevelFlags argument (instead of ignoring it).

The simplest course of action would be, imho:
- write a small mapper function from GLogLevelFlags to TerminalVerbosity (can't be perfect since the two models don't seem to match : bitmask vs ordered integers)
- call terminal_printerr_level  with the mapped level from terminal_log_writer
- also fix terminal_printerr* to call terminal_prerr_level instead of terminal_print_level (unrelated but seems to be a cut'n'paste error originally).

@chpe On principle, would a small patch doing that be accepted for review (i can write it) ?

events.target_title: Unnecessary logging (?) of media-keys plugin

note.body:
I wrote the patch (attached). Note that it just uses the g log level as a hint. gnome-terminal's log still won't honor G_DEBUG_MESSAGES=all and such, but will only react to increased verbosity (e.g. with -v on the command line).
With my patch : 
- ./gnome-terminal is silent
- ./gnome-terminal -v -v displays the messages referenced in this issue (and displays them on stderr instead of stdout).

Note this patch changes the behavior to printing error messages (as per the terminal_printerr_*) to stderr instead of stdout. It's easy to revert that aspect.

[gt_silence_log.patch](/uploads/53e612497fcfe5e4dc222746d6b9e0e5/gt_silence_log.patch)

events.target_title: PDF's link annotation does not work in version 3.30.2
PDF's link annotation does not work in version 3.30.2

note.body: Add one more comment, it seems that Evince recognize it, since Evince's context menu shows an entry 'Go To'. Both clicking the link annotation directly and choosing the 'Go To' menu item don't work.

events.target_title: PDF's link annotation does not work in version 3.30.2

note.body:
Thank you,Germán Poo-Caamaño. Maybe it is a bug instead of missing features. I looked into the example PDF again. The string for the named destinations in the example PDF seems containing control sequences such as marks of begin / end of bold style for fonts. So there are some unprintable characters which may depends on the software that generates the PDF file. These characters are not utf-8 characters actually. Such a string is legal in PDF if I understand correctly. Not sure if this is the culprit or not.

I don't have poppler-glib-demo currently, so I can't go with that direction further.

Also, not sure if Okular uses poppler only as its PDF backend, it deals with the example PDF well. My Okular version is 1.3.2.

events.target_title: PDF's link annotation does not work in version 3.30.2

note.body: Just took a peek of ev-link-dest.c, in struct _EvLinkDestPrivate there is one member 'named' of type 'gchar *' which is 'char *', not sure if this is to hold the name of a named destination for PDF documents. If so, then here is a problem. The string in PDF seems legal to contain character '\0', but if only a char * is used, there is no way to tell where the char array pointed by 'named' ends. Probably it needs some mechanism to convert between PDF string and C char *. One possible solution is to add a variable for length (quick but not ideal), the other solution is to use some encoding, such as escaping, to translate between them. Not sure if this is related to the problem reported, or it is already implemented in Evince. Just some thought for strings.

events.target_title: PDF's link annotation does not work in version 3.30.2

note.body: Hi, Germán Poo-Caamaño, thank you for the explanations. Yes, it seems only associated with things using glib. But it is still a little too early to conclude that the bug is only from poppler-glib. If the bug is due to the different definitions of string in PDF and programming languages, then both poppler and Evince should take care of that. Not sure if the code block I mentioned is the right place (maybe it is not related to PDF's named destination's name at all, just names given by Evince, such as "1", "2"...), it just shows an example of possible incomplete implementations.

events.target_title: PDF's link annotation does not work in version 3.30.2

note.body: I just tested with poppler-glib-demo. It didn't print any message or error. But the link annotations' contents, name, modified fields are empty. Not sure if it should show such info for normal PDF files.

events.target_title: PDF's link annotation does not work in version 3.30.2

note.body: Yes, I got the error messages by following your instruction. Thank you. I peeked that file firstly. I didn't find any suspicious code. I couldn't try to understand all the codes, but my suspicion in Evince is that libdocument design is not general enough to deal with various document types, such as PDF's string in its named destinations. If it takes a PDF string from a named destination literally in struct _EvLinkDestPrivate's named field and use it to refer to a PDF destination (for example, truncated by '\0' can make one name accidentally collide with another one, then the PDF destination returned by searching the name stored by 'named' can be a wrong one. Or Evince can't find any destination by searching that name. Just an example, maybe Evince uses some other method such as a pointer as a reference to a destination), then a bugfix in upstream poppler-glib may be not enough to eliminate this bug in Evince.

events.target_title: PDF's link annotation does not work in version 3.30.2

note.body: Hi, Jose Aliste, thank you, your patch should solve this bug in poppler-glib. If poppler is PDF only in the near future (no other document type included), a solution using escaping is essentially the same as a solution using byte array representations, such as GString, GByteArray, GBytes. Named destination related operations are not quite often, a little extra time on conversion won't affect performance. Only one thing should be kept in mind, named_dest is public accessible in struct _PopplerDest, which means potentially users may access it instead of using compress_string() for reading and escape_string() for storing. Is it already exposed in API's (I mean, the functions / documents poppler-glib provides to users)?
